doc.field: Small amounts of radioactivity set free in autobahn accident

Last night an accident happened on the A5 motorway near Heppenheim, Hessen, and light-radioactive waste in barrels and cans fell on the road. Police reported that small amounts of radioactivity had escaped. There was, however, no danger for humans. The load was pharmaceuticals use in nuclear medicine. The driver was slightly injured in the accident.
Nestle extorted again

The Nestle group has pulled its products from 44 Grosso supermarkets in Baden-Wuerttemberg and Bavaria as a reaction to a new extortion attempt. Nestle stated that the extortionists have threatened to poison products of the Nestle, Maggi, Thomy and Alete brand. During the past weeks all over Germany products with small amounts of poison had been found. On Monday, Nestle had received a letter demanding money in the million-mark range. Nestle recommended its customers to check thoroughly all goods bought since Saturday in Grosso supermarkets. The Stuttgart Interior Ministry stated that the Economy Control Service seized 29 suspicious items.
Schroeder's first visit to Russia

German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder has commented his first visit to Russia positively. At his closing press conference he said that Germany had a special role in helping Russia to overcome the economic crisis. Germany had gained experience in the restructuring of the DDR planned economy. This experience could now be of use for Russia. Schroeder, however, excluded again any direct financial aid. Addressing his talk with President Boris Yeltsin, Schroeder said that the President had actively taken part in the dialogue and appeared informed in detail.
President Herzog optimistic about Middle-East peace process

German President Roman Herzog has voiced optimism about the progress of the Middle-East peace process in spite of the tension between Israelis and Palestinians. This morning, Herzog met with Israel's Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu and then travelled to Jericho to talk with Palestinian President Yassir Arafat.
Coalition parties approve eco tax bill

The parliamentary factions of Social-Democrats and Buendnis90/Die Gruenen (B90/G) have approved the bill for the eco tax. This clears the way for introducing the bill in the Bundestag for its first reading on Friday. The coalition intends to have the law in effect by January 1. The eco tax is to garner 11.3 billion marks next year. The government wants to use the money to reduce the contributions to the pension plan by 0.8 percentage points to 19.5 percent. The bill provides that taxes on gasoline and diesel increase by 6 pfennigs, heating fuel by 4 pfennigs per litre. Gas prices will rise by 0.32 pfennigs and electricity by 2 pfennigs per kilowatt-hour (kWh), specially priced power for night storage heaters will increase by 1 pfennig per kWh. B90/G resolved that also in future the eco tax alone is to finance the reduction of wage fringe costs.
Economic experts expect smaller growth

The Handelsblatt newspaper reports that the group of economic experts, also known as the Five Wise Men, predict 2.0 percent economic growth in 1999 and 2.75 percent for 1998. The reason for the decline is supposedly the financial crisis in Asia. The experts also predict only a slight improvement in the unemployment rate, a decrease from 11.2 to 10.8 percent next year. The Handelsblatt reports further that the experts criticize the government's tax plans. The net tax relief for citizens and enterprises was too late and too low.
Germany wants to stick to fixed prices for books

Germany wants to challenge in the European Court a looming prohibition of the book price fixing between Austria and Germany. This was announced by Germany's commissioner for culture in the EU Cultural Council in Brussels. Books were a cultural good and could not be viewed only under competition aspects. EU Competition Commissioner Karel van Miert wants to dissolve the cross-border price fixing in early 1999 because it is distorting competition.
Consequences from "Pallas" accident announced

The government of Schleswig-Holstein will draw its consequences from the Pallas accident in the North Sea. State Premier Heide Simonis announced a comprehensive review that would lead to a new safety concept for coastal waters. This would prevent future misjudgements. The fire on the stranded timber freighter Pallas could not be extinguished yet. Wind gusts rekindled the fire repeatedly. Tomorrow, the fire is to be put out finally. The Environment Ministry reported that no new oil has been washed ashore.
Berlin Olympic stadium to be restructured

The Administrative Secretaries of the Berlin government have agreed on a restructuring of the Berlin Olympic arena for more than 500 million marks. The plans of a Hamburg architect include flexible stands and a half-open roof. The new arena will seat 77,000. Chancellor Schroeder has promised the German soccer association a federal subsidy of 100 million marks.
First day of trade of DaimlerChrysler stocks

The stocks of the newly created automobile group DaimlerChrysler have been traded today for the first time. The two heads of the third largest car manufacturer, Mr. Schrempf and Mr. Eaton were satisfied with the trading. In Frankfurt the first notation of the share in the floor trading was 142.20 DM, a clear plus. In New York, too, the rate increased slightly during the first day although the Dow Jones index decreased slightly. The new enterprise with a total of 428,000 employees is targeting returns of 260 billion marks for this year. Following the fusion of the car manufacturers Germany's largest aerospace company will also change name. Starting today the DASA is called DaimlerChrysler Aerospace.
Lufthansa on the way up

Lufthansa is booming. The company reported that its profit doubled during the first nine months of this year. For this year Lufthansa targets a profit of 2 billion marks before taxes. Five thousand new jobs will be created until 2001.
